revisionDesc.change: revised Yao, Skinazi, Chapman, Cole, Lines, Hunter bios.

note.p: See the Biography for biographical information on Winnifred Eaton.
Mary Chapman is the Director of The Winnifred Eaton Archive and teaches American literature at University of British Columbia.

Mary Chapman is the Director of The Winnifred Eaton Archive and teaches American literature at University of British Columbia. She is the author of the award-winning monograph Making Noise, Making News: Suffrage Print Culture and US Modernism (Oxford UP) and of numerous articles about American literature and women writers. She has also edited Becoming Sui Sin Far: Early Fiction, Journalism and Travel Writing by Edith Maude Eaton (McGill-Queen’s UP) and published essays on the Eaton sisters in American Quarterly, MELUS, Legacy, Canadian Literature, and American Periodicals. Her current research project is a microhistory of the Eaton family. For more information, see http://faculty.arts.ubc.ca/mchapman/.

Jean Lee Cole is Senior Consultant on The Winnifred Eaton Archive, author of The Literary Voices of Winnifred Eaton: Redefining Ethnicity and Authenticity (2002), co-editor of A Japanese Nightingale and Madame Butterfly: Two Orientalist Texts (2002, with Maureen Honey), and editor of the original Winnifred Eaton Digital Archive (2004). She is Professor of English at Loyola University Maryland.

Sydney Lines is a PhD student in English at the University of British Columbia and a research assistant for the UBC Public Humanities Hub and the Winnifred Eaton Archive. Her research focuses on the nationalist myth-making of long nineteenth-century representations of Old Norse literature and culture in the British Isles.

person.note: Ken Ip is a graduate of the MA program in English at the University of British Columbia and was a research assistant for the Winnifred Eaton Archive.

note.p: Joey Takeda is an MA student in English at the University of British Colubmia and a digital humanities programmer for the Winnifred Eaton Archive and other projects. His research focuses primarily on Indigenous and diasporic literatures written in Canada.

Joey Takeda is an MA student at the University of British Columbia (Department of English Language and Literature, Science and Technology Studies Research Stream). His current research attends to Indigenous and diasporic understandings of the underground as a vibrant space that goes beyond the current extractivist paradigms of settler-colonialism. More broadly, his research focuses on Indigenous and diasporic literature written in what is currently called North America, the digital humanities, media studies, and critical theory.

He also works as a digital humanities programmer, specializing in XML technologies. He has worked for a number of DH projects, including The Map of Early Modern London, Linked Early Modern Drama Online, The Stratford Promptbook Protocol. His code can be found on his Github page and his academic CV can be found on his website.

person.note: Samantha Bowen is an Honours English student at University of British Columbia and a research assistant for the Winnifred Eaton Archive.
Serina Patterson is a web designer and designed the Winnifred Eaton Reeve website.
Hilary Ball is a graduate of the MA program in English at the University of British Columbia and was a research assistant for the Winnifred Eaton Archive.

note.p: Christine Xine Yao is Lecturer in American Literature to 1900 at University College London. Her first book Disaffected: The Cultural Politics of Unfeeling in Nineteenth-Century America is under contract with Duke University Press.

person.note: Pavlina Pajot is a PhD student in English at the University of British Columbia.
Lucia Maggio is an undergraduate in Japanese Studies at the University of Hokkaido.
Diana Birchall is the author of Onoto Watanna: The Story of Winnifred Eaton and the granddaughter of Winnifred Eaton.

note.p: Karen E. H. Skinazi is the Director of Liberal Arts at the University of Bristol. She writes about women’s literature and republished Winnifred’s 1916 novel Marion: The Story of an Artist’s Model with a long introduction situating the text in a history of passing narratives (McGill-Queen’s University Press, 2012). She contributed a headnote for an instalment of Marion on The Winnifred Eaton Archive.

Shaun Hunter is the author of Calgary through the Eyes of Writers (Rocky Mountain Books, 2018) and consultant for an exhibition of the same name, featuring Winnifred Eaton, at the Lougheed House in Calgary.
